subject: Re[2]: [junit] junit on large scale

messageBody:
>>Hi - I'm attempting to introduce junit testing techniques into where I work.
>>So far I've used it on a small scale, writing junit tests for enhancement
>>changes to existing code.
>>We have some large projects, along the lines of web booking engines for
>>travel agents, that already exist. One of the concerns that I (and
>>developers) have is that we will end up with thousands of test cases, many
>>of which will involve using substantial amounts of MockObjects to set up
>>test cases and that all this will become too much of an overhead to manage
>>maintain. Specifically,Â  that changing code in the future will involve
>>analysis of not only the project code but also the junit test code - an
>>overhead we don't have today of course.

Yes, don't look at the tests as overhead. Look at them as short-cuts
that help you understand. For instance, often it is great to know
that:

assertEquals(0, floogle.flumox(12))
and assertEquals(1, floogle.flumox(13))

without calculating it out by hand.

The other reason why they help is because they act as a "software
vise." They hold down the behavior of your system and let you know
when you are changing more behavior than you expected to. That alone
is invaluable in development.

Tests make maintenance easier because they hack away at uncertainty.

Michael Feathers
